Comparison of S(+)-ketamine and ketamine,  
with medetomidine, for field anesthesia in the 
European brown hare ( Lepus europaeus ) 
 
 
 
 
  
DIPLOMARBEIT 
 
  
zur Erlangung der Würde des 
Diplom Tierarztes 
 
 
vorgelegt von 
 
Hanno Gerritsmann

5 
 Einleitung 
Der Europäische Feldhase (EFH) ( Lepus europaeus ) gehört zur Ordnung der Hasenartigen 
(Lagomporpha ) und zur Familie der Hasen ( Leporidae ). Derzeit sind 79 Spezies innerhalb der 
Ordnung bekannt, wovon 19 von der International Union for Conservation of Nature and 
Natural Resources (IUCN) als gefährdet ei ngestuft sind (Grizmek 2003). Eines der am 
stärksten gefährdeten Säugetiere überhaupt ist der  Buschmannhase ( Bunolagus monticularis).   
Der EFH ist im Bereich der Wildtierforschun g, insbesondere hinsichtlich seiner Genetik 
sowie Reproduktion und Physiologie, seit langem von Interesse. Am Forschungsinstitut für 
Wildtierkunde und Ökologie (FIWI) der Veterinär medizinischen Universität Wien wird die 
Art seit 25 Jahren  für Studienzwecke gehalten. 
Im Mai 2010 kam es aus ungeklärter Ursache zu einer Bestandsinfektion mit Pasteurellen, 
Bordetellen und mucoiden E.Coli, die seuchenhaft fortschritt und in deren Verlauf 15 Hasen 
verstarben. Aus diesem Grund wurde vom Institut für Bakteriologie, Mykologie und Hygiene 
der Veterinärmedizinischen Universität Wien ei ne stall-spezifische Vakzine hergestellt. Zum 
Zeitpunkt der Impfung wurde eine Blutprobe zur späteren Antikörper-Titerbestimmung 
genommen. 
Lagomorphe gelten generell als sehr stressemp findlich (West et al. 2009). Da die Feldhasen 
des FIWI keinen Kontakt zum Menschen gewohnt sind, müssen die Tiere zur routinemäßigen 
medizinischen Versorgung anästhesiert werden. So auch für diese Blutentnahme. 
In der Literatur gibt es keine Empfehlungen oder gar ein Standardprotokoll für die Feldhasen-
Narkose. Eine direkte Übertragung von Erfahrungen aus der Kaninchen Anästhesie ist 
grundsätzlich kritisch zu betrachten, da es s ich um verschiedene Arten handelt (West et al. 
2009). 
In der Literatur fanden sich Feldhasen Studie n, die auch invasive Maßnahmen beinhalteten. 
So wurde von Gustavsson (1972) eine unila terale Kastration von adulten Feldhasen 
ausschließlich unter Lokalanästhesie mit Lidocain durchgeführt. Caillol et al. (1992) führten 
unter Thiopental-Mononarkosen La parotomien durch. Röllig (2008)  fixierte die Tiere manuell 
durch zwei Personen und benutze Maskeneinlei tung sowie Erhaltung mit Isofluran als 
Anästhesieprotokoll für ihre Untersuchunge n. Diese Techniken sind ohne Zweifel für 
chirurgische Eingriffe nicht mehr zeitgemäß. Kombinationen aus Ketamin und einem α
2-Agonisten sind in der Wildtieranästhesie weit 
verbreitet und wurden bereits bei diversen Spezies erfolgreich eingesetzt (West et al. 2009).  
  
6 
 Ketamin 
Ketamin gehört chemisch zu den Cyclohexanderivaten. In der Anästhesie fällt es neben 
Tiletamin in die Klasse der dissoziativen Anästhet ika. Patienten, die mit Ketamin anästhesiert 
sind,  erscheinen in einem kataleptoiden Zusta nd, der durch Muskelstarre, aber gute Analgesie 
und Amnesie gekennzeichnet ist (Riviere & Papich 2009). Die dissoziative Wirkung kommt 
durch die unterschiedlichen Wirkorte de s Ketamins zustande. Thalamoneokortikale 
Leitungsbahnen werden, bei gleichzeitiger Stim ulierung limbischer Areale, gehemmt (Kress 
1997).  
Das in der Tiermedizin klinisch verwendete Ketaminhydrochlorid stellt eine gleichteilige 
Mischung seiner beiden Stereoisomere S-(+)- bzw. R-(-)-Ketamin, die sich stereoselektiv in 
ihren Effekten unterscheiden, dar. Die Wirkungswei se der dissoziativen Anästhetika ist in den 
vergangenen Jahren immer weiter aufgeklärt  worden. Ihre Hauptwirkung entwickeln beide 
Ketamin Stereoisomere an der Phencyclidin (PCP)-Bindungsstelle im N-Methyl-D-Aspartat 
(NMDA)-Rezeptorkanal, einem postsynaptischen, ionotropen Glutamat-Rezeptor. Hier 
hemmen sie den Effekt der NMDA-Rezeptor A gonisten nicht kompetitiv. S-(+)-Ketamin hat 
beim Menschen eine 3-4 fach höhere Affini tät zur PCP-Bindungsstelle als das R-(-)-Isomer 
(Hempelmann & Kuhn 1997). Die Rezeptoraffinität der Isomere am PCP-Rezeptor im 
NMDA-Rezeptorkanal entspricht nicht nur deren inhibitorischen Eigenschaften, sondern 
erklärt auch das anästhetische und analgetisc he Potential der Isomere sehr gut (Kress 1997). 
Hochdosiertes R-(-)-Ketamin führt beim Me nschen mitunter zu Exzitationen und 
Halluzinationen. Dies legt eine Beteiligung de r ehemals als Opiat-Re zeptoren bezeichneten 
σ1,2-Rezeptoren, sowie der κ-Opiat-Rezeptoren nahe. Ketaminwi rkung an Opiatrezeptoren ist 
nachgewiesen (Finck & Ngai 1982). Die Affiniät des S-(+)-Isomers an μ- und κ-Rezeptoren 
in Meerschweinchenhirn-Homogenat ist 2-4 mal höher als die des R-(-)-Isomers und ist 
generell μ>κ>δ (Kress 1997). Generell ist die Affi nität zu den Opiatrezeptoren bei μ-Rezeptor 
10 mal und bei κ-Rezeptor 20 mal so hoch wie gegenüber der PCP-Bindungstelle. Heute weiß 
man, dass die Ketaminwirkung an den Opiatrezptoren nur teilweise die analgetischen 
Eigenschaften bedingt, da sie nicht vollständig durch Naloxon antagonisierbar ist (Kress 
1997). Weiterhin hat Ketamin Einfluss auf ni kotinische Acetylcholin Rezeptorkanäle 
(nAChR) und muskarinische Acetylcholinrezeptoren (mAChR), sowie die Ausschüttung und 
Re-uptake der Neurotransmitter Noradrenalin  und Dopamin. Durch direkte Beeinflussung von 
spannungsgesteuerten Natriumkanälen er zielt Ketamin weiterhin seine bekannten 
lokalanästhetischen Effekte (Kress 1997).  
7 
 Ketamin wird hauptsächlich durch mikrosomale En zyme in der Leber abgebaut. Es erfolgt 
eine N-Demethylierung zum aktiven Metaboliten  Norketamin, welcher zum Teil hydroxiliert 
wird. Sowohl Norketamin als auch Hydroxynorketamin werden zu wasserlöslichen 
Glucuroniden konjugiert und mit dem Urin ausges chieden (White et al. 1982). Hierbei wird 
das S-(+)-Enantiomer um 20% schneller meta bolisiert als das R-(-)-Enantiomer. Dieses 
wiederum wird um 10% schneller metabolisier t als das Razemat (Kharasch & Labroo 1992). 
Kharasch & Labroo (1992) zeigten, dass bei al len Konzentrationen (gleiche Anzahl von 
Ketamin-Molekülen) das Razemat langsamer abgebaut wird als die Enantiomere jeweils 
einzeln. Dem liegt eine gegenseitige Hemm ung des Abbaus zugrunde, was eine kürzere 
Wirkdauer von S-(+)-Ketamin erklären würde. 
 
α2-Agonisten 
Alle α2-Agonisten, mit Ausnahme des Xylazins, gehören chemisch in die Gruppe der 
Imidazole. Generell haben die α2-Agonisten sowohl sedierendes als auch analgetisches und 
muskelrelaxierendes Potential (Riviere & Papich 2009). 
α2-Agonisten wirken unter anderem an α2A-Rezeptoren, die (G Protein vermittelt) Typ-N 
Calciumkanäle schließen und zur Hyperpolarisat ion der prä- und postsynaptischen Zelle 
führen. Dadurch kommt es zur Inhibition des positiven Feedbacks und damit zu reduzierter 
Ausschüttung von Noradrenalin aus der präsynap tischen Zelle in den synaptischen Spalt. 
Über die reduzierte  Ausschüttung von Noradrenalin, vor allem im Locus coeruleus und 
Hypothalamus, aber auch anderer Bereiche des Ge hirns, wird letztlich die sedierende 
Wirkung erzielt (Riviere & Papich 2009). Die α2-Agonisten vermittelte Analgesie kommt, 
soweit derzeit bekannt, durch den gleichen Prozess im Zentralnervensystem (ZNS) zustande. 
Je nach Art der Verabreichung sind Rezeptoren im Locus coeruleus  und in der Substantia 
gelatinosa  des Dorsalhorns des Rückenmarks invol viert oder, bei epiduraler Anwendung, 
hauptsächlich die  Rezeptoren in der Substantia gelatinosa  des Dorsalhorns (Riviere & Papich 
2009). 
Das derzeit noch überwiegend genutzte razemisc he Medetomidin liegt als Gemisch aus 2 
Enatiomeren vor, wobei sich ausschließlich das D-Isomer als pharmakologisch wirksam 
erwiesen hat (Kharasch et al. 1992). Das L-Iso mer scheint als kompetitiver inverser Agonist 
zu wirken (es setzt am gleichen Rezeptor an, ab er reduziert seine Aktivität (Riviere & Papich 
2009), was möglicherweise die Wirksamkeit des Razemats beeinflusst. Beide Isomere haben 
zudem starken Einfluss auf den hepatischen Abba u anderer Pharmaka (Kharasch et al. 1992).   
8 
 Bei vorhergegangen Anästhesien der Feldhasen des Instituts mit dieser Kombination wurde 
trotz Antagonisierung der α2-Komponente mitunter langer Nachschlaf (recovery time) 
beobachtet. Insbesondere hinsichtlich eines für die Feldanästhesie geeigneten Protokolls sind 
Regenerationszeit sowie unerwünschte Nebenwirkungen möglichst gering zu halten. 
Auf Grund entsprechender Literatursuche wurde die Hypothese entwickelt, dass die Nutzung 
von S-(+)-Ketamin statt razemischem Ketamin nebe n einem äquivalenten, für chirurgische 
Eingriffe  geeigneten, Anästhesiestadium auch  den Vorteil einer kürzeren Aufwachphase mit 
weniger unerwünschten Nebenwirkungen produzier en könnte (White et al. 1980; White et al. 
1982; Erhardt et al. 2001; Kiliç & Henke 2004; Rossetti et al. 2008). 
Demzufolge wurden beide Protokolle hinsichtl ich signifikanter Unterschiede, mit besonderem 
Augenmerk auf die Parameter der Aufwachphase, verglichen.  
In Anlehnung an gängige Praktiken der veterinärmedizinischen Anästhesie wurden folgende 
Parameter zur vergleichenden Beurteilun g der Narkosezeiten herangezogen.  
 
 
Tab. 1a : Parameter der Aufwachphase 
 
Parameter Englisch Definition 
Erstreaktionszeit  Reaction time  Zeit (Minute n) Applikation bis erste Reaktion auf 
Medikation  
Wirkungszeit  Time until full effect  Zeit (Minuten) Applikation bis Verlust des Stellreflexes  
Narkosezeit  Total anesthesia 
time Zeit (Minuten) Applikation bis zum ersten selbstständigen   
Anheben des Kop fes 
Aufstehzeit  Standing time  Zeit (Minuten) von Antagonisierung bis zum Zeitpunkt, an 
dem das Tier auf vier Beinen steht  
Regenerationszeit  Recovery time  Zeit (Minuten) ab Aufstehzeit bis zur völligen 
Abwesenheit aller Zeichen einer Anästhesie  
 Um ein möglichst objektives Maß für eine  potentiell erhöhte Motoraktivität bei der 
Verwendung von razemischen Ketamin zu erhalten, wurden noch folgende Parameter 
hinzugefügt. Es wurde eine Strichliste über die Anzahl der Vorgänge geführt.  
  
9 
  
Tab. 1b.: Zusätzliche Parameter der Aufwachphase nach Gabe von Ketamin respektive 
S-(+)-Ketamin 
Parameter Englisch Definition 
Umfallen  Falling over  Aus stabiler P osition oder im Zuge einer Bewegung 
umfallen  
Auf der Seite 
rudern  Pedaling on the side  Auf der Seite liegend u nkoordiniert rudern 
(Aufrichtev ersuche)  
 
 
 
Abschließend wurde die Aufwachphase mit Hilf e einer Visual Analoge Scale (VAS), mit 
folgender Begrenzung, subjektiv beurteilt. 
 
Grafik 1.: 
 
                          Sehr schlecht                                                                              Perfekt    
 
Mit Hilfe der oben erwähnten Parameter wu rde versucht, durch die Kombination von 
objektiven und subjektiven Maßen, eine bestmögl iche Beurteilung der Anästhesie, sowie der 
Aufwachphase zu gewährleisten. Die Parameter wurden, in Ermangelung umfangreicher 
Literatur bezüglich Fel dhasenanästhesie, in Anlehnung an Grundsätze der Wildtieranästhesie 
(West et al. 2009), sowie einschlägiger Fachliteratur (Portier et al. 2010) gewählt. 
Um Beeinflussung der beteiligten Anästhesisten möglichst gering zu halten, wurden diese 
bezüglich der jeweils verwende ten Wirkstoffe geblendet.  
Der Fragestellung, ob Kombinationen von Medetomidin mit S-(+)-Ketamin Vorteile, 
insbesondere hinsichtlich der Aufwachphase, gegenüber der Kombination von Medetomidin 
und razemischen Ketamin aufweist, wurde nach Ab schluss der Planungstätigkeiten in einem 
zweiwöchigen, praktischen Teil  ab dem 27.10.2010 nachgegangen. 
 
  
  
10

Siehe Manuskript - References 
 
 
 
  
11 
 Manuskript für die Einreichung  
 
The m anuscript will be submitted to the journal „Veterinary Anesthesia and Analgesia” in 
January 2011. 
 
Comparison of S(+)-ketamine and ketamine, with medetomidine, for field anesthesia in 
the 
European brown hare ( Lepus europaeus ) 
 
Authors: Hanno Gerritsmann ¹, Gabrielle Stalder, Mag. med. vet. ¹, Katharina Seilern-
Moy ¹, Felix Knauer Dr. silv. ¹ and Chri s Walzer, Dr. med. vet., Univ. Prof. ¹  
 
¹ Research Institute of Wildlife Ecology, Un iversity of Veterinary Medicine, A-1160 Vienna, 
Austria 
 
 
Corresponding author:   
Hanno Gerritsmann   
Research Institute of Wildlife Ecology  
University of Veterinary Medicine  
A-1160 Vienna  
AUSTRIA  
Phone: +43 650 3805011 
E-mail: hanno.gerritsmann@fiwi.at 
 
Keywords  field anesthesia, European brown hare, S(+)-ketamine,  Lepus europaeus , 
medetomidine, atipamezole 
 
 
 
  
 
  
12 
  
Abstract 
Objective 
To compare the induction, achievement of surgical anesthesia, cardiopulmonary effects and 
especially recovery quality of racemic ketamine or S(+)-ketamine when used in combination 
with medetomidine for intramuscular (IM) field anesthesia in the European brown hare (EBH) 
(Lepus europaeus ). 
 
Study design Randomized, prospective, bl inded clinical trial. 
 
Animals  20 adult European brown hares (10 male, 10 female) with a body mass of 3360 (± 
341) grams. 
 
Methods Medetomidine (0.2 mg kg-1) and ketamine (30 mg kg-1) (K-M group) or S(+)-
ketamine (15 mg kg-1) (S-M group) were administered by IM  injection. Time until first effect 
and loss of righting reflex were recorded. During maintenance heart rate (HR), saturation of 
arterial hemoglobin (SpO 2), respiratory rate (RR), side stream expiratory CO 2 (etCO 2), non 
invasive blood pressure, body temperature (temp), palpebral reflex, jaw tone and pain 
sensation were recorded every five minutes. 45 minutes after injection of the medication, 
medetomidine was antagonized with atipamezole (1 mg kg-1). Time until first head lift, time 
until standing and total recovery time (T-Recov) were recorded. Incidences of falling over to 
the side (falling) and pedaling while in later al recumbency (pedaling) during recovery were 
counted for each animal. A visual analogue s cale (VAS) was used to determine the subjective 
impression of recovery quality. Mean weight, time until first effect and loss of righting reflex, 
HR, SpO 2, etCO 2, temp as well as the recovery para meters falling, pedaling, T-Recov and 
quality were compared using an unpaired t-test. Mean values for all other data were compared 
using a Mann-Whitney test. 
 
Results Induction was similar in both groups. During maintenance respiratory parameters 
were significantly better for the S-M group. Surgical anesthesia was achieved at significantly 
more points of measurement in the K-M group (56.3 ± 9.2%) vs. the S-M group (42.5 ± 
12.8%). During recovery, animals of the S-M group (12.5 ± 6.7) fell over to the side less often  
13 
 than animals of K-M group (27.2 ± 12.6). Overal l, T-Recov did not differ significantly 
between groups and was long, lasting for more than three hours in some animals. 
Conclusion and clinical relevance S(+)-ketamine showed only minor advantages over 
racemic ketamine, surgical anesthesia was not ach ieved reliably with either protocol. Both, 
racemic- and S(+)-ketamine in combination wi th medetomidine, at the dosages used, are 
considered inadequate for field anesthesia in th e EBH. Further research is needed to develop 
an injectable protocol that allows surgical procedures and rapid recoveries.  
 
Keywords:  field anesthesia, European brown hare, Lepus europaeus , S(+)-ketamine, 
medetomidine, atipamezole 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
14 
 Introduction  
The European brown hare (EBH) ( Lepus europaeus ) belongs to the order of Lagomorphs and 
is a species distributed widely from northern Sp ain through western and central Europe to the 
northwestern parts of Mongolia (Grizmek 2003) . Introduced populations are found in several 
parts of the world including Australia, New Ze aland, southern South America and parts of the 
United States of America (Grizmek 2003). 
In the past, the EBH has been the subject of numerous research questions, including studies 
on reproduction (Gustavsson 1972; Caillol et al. 1992; Röllig 2008 ) which included invasive 
techniques. Even though literature concerning anesthesia in rabbits is common, specific 
information concerning anesthesia in the EBH is very scarce.  
Caillol et al. (1992) used thiopenthone at 20 mg kg-1 when performing laparotomy and 
Gustavsson (1972) performed unilateral orchiecto my in adult males under local anesthesia 
with xylocaine. Röllig (2008)  restrained animals physically with two assistants, while a third 
induced anesthesia with 5% isoflurane via face-mask. Subsequently, anesthesia was 
maintained with 1 - 1.5% isoflurane. West et  al. (2009) encourage box induction over mask 
induction for Lagomorphs. 
In any case, isoflurane anesthesia alone cannot be considered adequate for surgery since it 
does not provide sufficient analgesia (West et al . 2009; Erhardt et al. 2004). Furthermore, in a 
field setting, administration of isoflurane migh t be impracticable and an induction box for an 
adult EBH would have to be qui te large and stable since this species is larger than most 
rabbits and of respectable strength when stressed and attempting to escape. 
The objective of this study was to compare two simple injectable anesthetic protocols for field 
anesthesia in the EBH in order to obtain an improved recovery phase, while producing safe 
and adequate anesthesia for invasive procedures.  
Ketamine combined with α2-agonists had previously been used for procedures involving the 
animals routinely held at the Institute of Wi ldlife Ecology (University of Veterinary 
Medicine, Vienna, Austria). During these procedures, long recovery times had been noted.  
Since a short recovery is an important factor in  wild animal anesthesia, it was decided to 
compare a racemic ketamine – medetomidine protocol with a S(+)-ketamine – medetomidine 
protocol. It has been reported previously in other species that S(+)-ketamine has significantly 
less undesired side effects regarding recovery  than racemic ketamine (White et al. 1982; 
Erhardt et al. 2001; Kiliç & Henke 2004; Rossetti et al . 2008). 
  
15 
 Materials & Methods 
In October 2010, 89 European brown hares ( Lepus europaeus ) held routinely by the Institute 
of Wildlife Ecology (University of Veterina ry Medicine, Vienna, Austria = UVMV) needed 
to be vaccinated with an enclosure-specific vaccine against Pasteurella and Bordetella  
produced by the Institute for Bacteriology, Mycology and Hygiene (University of Veterinary 
Medicine, Vienna, Austria). Additionally, 5 ml  of blood were drawn from 54 hares from the 
left jugular vein for antibody titer assessment.  
The hares are individually housed in wooden cages with grid flooring, inside an open stable. 
Temperatures in the cages correspond to outside environmental temperatures. Floor area is 0.5 
m² per animal. All hares are fed on specially p roduced hare pellet diet (Hasenfuttermittel, 
Raiffeisenverband Salzburg, Austria). 
 
The study described in this publication was part of the routine clinical work of the institute 
and noted and approved by the UVMV ethics co mmission. In addition, all trials described 
were in concordance with Austri an animal welfare legislation. 
 
Of the 54 hares used for antibody titer assessmen t, 20 adult hares of both sexes (n = 10 males, 
n = 10 females) with a mean body mass of 3.36 ± 0.34 kg were randomly assigned to either 
one of the following groups: 
 S-M (receiving S(+)-ketamine and medetomidine)  
 K-M (receiving racemic ke tamine and medetomidine)  
Since literature on EBH anesthesia was scarce and to the author ’s best knowledge no 
scientifically performed anesthetic protocol in cluding either agent was available, the day 
before the study, 2 animals were anesthetized for antibody titer assessment using 10 mg kg-1 
S(+)-ketamine and 100 μg kg-1 medetomidine. Immobilization was accomplished, but state of 
anesthesia was light. Only after this it was d ecided to increase dosages to those employed in 
the study. 
 
On the days of the procedure each individual wa s caught from its cage with a catch box of 
known weight, made specifically for this purpose . Immediately thereafter the animal was 
weighed within the box and the box then placed  on the floor with the grid opening in contact 
with a wall to reduce possible ex citation by audiovisual stimuli . All hares in the study 
appeared clinically healthy on visual and behavioral adspection. The animal's mental  
16 
 condition was evaluated by observing attempts to escape from the catch box by eagerly 
scratching the walls. Two distinctions were mad e: calm vs. excited. Animals were recorded as 
calm when the scratching ceased after one mi nute of being put on the floor. If scratching 
continued for a longer period of time the animals were marked as excited. 
 
Subsequently, the catch box was placed on a table  and the hare was physically restrained by 
an experienced assistant for drug applicati on. Additionally, treatment order was randomized 
and the observers blinded. Each animal underwent anesthesia once. 
Racemic ketamine (100 mg ml-1; Ketasol; Graeub, Berne, Switzerland) or S(+)-ketamine (25 
mg ml-1; S Ketanest; Pfizer, Vienna , Austria) were combined with medetomidine (10 mg ml-1; 
Zalopine; Orion Pharma, Espoo, Finland). 
 Group K-M received: Medetomidine (0.2 mg kg-1) and ketamine (30 mg kg-1)  
 Group S-M received: Medetomidine (0.2 mg kg-1) and S(+)-ketamine (15 mg kg-1) 
Drugs were mixed in a syringe and then given as  a single IM injection into the caudo-lateral 
aspect of the pelvic limb ( m. biceps femoris). The maximal injected volume was less than 2.5 
ml. 
To achieve equal injectable volumes with both protocols, racemic ketamine was diluted to 50 
mg ml-1 with aqua bidest (Aqua ad injectionem; Braun B., Maria Enzersdorf, Austria). 
After injection, the hare was immediately released  from physical restrain t and left in the catch 
box until full effect. During this time the grid  was facing the corner of the procedure-room. 
The observer kept a distance of 3.5 m to the box, closely monitoring any changes in behaviour 
of the animals. 
First effect, as well as loss of  righting reflex were recorded. Righting reflex was evaluated by 
slowly tilting the catch box 90° to the contra-lateral side of the animal ’s body position. When 
no reaction was present, the righting reflex co unted as negative. Time of loss of righting 
reflex was tested with a potential error of 20 seconds as the animal was only approached 
every 20 seconds to minimize potential flight behavior. 
After loss of righting reflex the hares were lef t in the catch box for an additional 2 minutes to 
allow the anesthetics to gain full effect.  In case of spontaneous movement upon opening, 
animals were left in the catch box for another 5 minutes until full effect was evident. 
The hares were then placed in right lateral recumbency. Eye ointment (Oleovit; Fresenius 
Kabi, Graz, Austria) was applied to the cornea to avert drying. To counteract a decrease in 
body temperature all hares were placed on a heating pad. Non invasive arterial blood pressure  
17 
 (systolic arterial pressure = S AP, mean arterial pressure = MAP and diastolic arterial pressure 
= DAP), body temperature (temp), satura tion of arterial hemoglobin (SpO2), side stream ET 
CO2  (etCO2) as well as pulse frequency and respiratory rate (RR) were measured using a 
Mindray PM-8000 Express, patient monitor (Mindray, China). 
NIBP was measured proximal of the left elbow (Ypsilantis et al. 2005). Body temperature was 
measured with a rectal probe which was inserted four centimeters in all animals. The pulse-
oximeter probe was placed on the animals tongue. The tube for side stream ET CO2 
measurement was placed in the hare's left nostril for 1 minute every five minutes.  
Palpebral reflex was tested for anesthetic depth by touching the naso-ventral canthus of the 
eye up to three times within 10 s. Compressing the P2 of the fourth digit of the left thoracical 
limb with a hemostat, engaged to first pitch three times within 20 seconds, was used for the 
evaluation of pain sensation. Surgical anesthesia  was judged to be present in the absence of 
reaction (increase of HR, RR, or movement) to  the third compression (Hedenqvist et al. 2001; 
Kiliç & Henke 2004). Muscle relaxation was evalu ated by checking jaw tone. All reflexes and 
jaw tone were always evaluated by the same person, blinded to the drug combination used. 
 
Time at injection of the anesthetics was de fined as T = 0 min. Evaluation of first 
physiological parameters and reflexes was dependent on induction time. In the S-M group 
first measurements were made six times at T = 10 min, three times at T = 15 min and once at 
T = 20 min. In the K-M group first measurements  were made eight times at T = 10 min and 
twice at T = 15 min.  From the onset of measurements, reflexes and physiological variables were recorded every 
five minutes until T = 45 min. At this time,  medetomidine was antagonized with 1 mg kg
-1 
atipamezole (5.0 mg ml-1; Antisedan; Orion Pharma, Espoo, Finland). 
Following atipamezole application, the hares were  returned to their cages. After four animals 
a case of high grade excitations was noted and subsequently a padded and darkened wake up 
box was constructed. All remaining 16 animals were placed in this wake up box for recovery 
and closely monitored.   
During recovery, the following variables were monitored by two anesthetists blinded about 
the protocol: 
Chewing, lift head time (T-Anesth = time from T = 0 until the first complete lift of the head), 
standing time (T-standing = time from antagoni zation until the animal stood on four feet for 
the first time) and recovery time (T-Recov = ti me until the animal was sitting alert and  
18 
 moving in a coordinated way, without showing signs of ataxia or anesthesia). Additionally, 
the number of times the hare fe ll over and pedaling while in lateral recumbency were taken as 
a measure of recovery status by counting the events  for 135 minutes post antagonization. As 
a measure for the subjective quality of the rec overy phase, the blinded anesthetist supervising 
the recovery phase placed a mark on a visual analogue scale (VAS). The scale was 100 mm 
long and anchored with “very poor” and “perfect”.  
 
Statistical Analysis 
Statistics were done using the Program R 2.9.2 (The R Foundation for Statistical Computing, 
Auckland, NZ ). Each dataset was tested for normal distribution using a Shapiro-Wilk 
normalitiy test. Since sample size was small, data were also plotted for normal distribution 
assessment. Mean values were compared using an unpaired t-test. Mean values for data that 
were not normally distributed were compared using a Mann-Whitney test.  
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
  
19 
 Results 
Pre-anesthetic evaluation 
There were no significant differences between groups regarding weight or the number of 
excited animals vs. the number of calm animals (Table 1). 
 
Induction of Anesthesia 
Ketamine or S(+)-ketamine and medetomidine were administered successfully to all animals 
via IM injection (into the m. biceps femoris ). When comparing first effect and the time to loss 
of righting reflex between the two groups, the S-M group tended to have a marginally shorter 
time until first effect than animals in the K-M group. Conversely, animals receiving racemic 
ketamine tended to have a slightly shorter time  until loss of righting reflex. However, 
differences were not significant (Figure 1). 
 Maintenance 
Overall mean values of physiological parameters are shown in Table 2. Physiological 
parameters over time are shown in Figures 2 a) - d). During the maintenance/duration of 
anesthesia mean values of HR (Figure 2a)), SAP (Figure 2b)) and body temperature did not 
differ significantly between groups. In two animals of the K-M group cardiac arrhythmia  
(differing from respiratory arrhythmia)  was recorded at the beginning of anesthesia. No pulse 
deficit was recorded during these episodes. 
Yet, mean respiratory parameters differed significantly between groups. Side stream ET CO
2 
(Figure 2c)) was significantly (p = 0.02) lower in the S-M group than in the K-M group (39 ± 7 vs. 41 ± 5 mmHg respectively). RR (Figure 2d)) in the S-M group was significantly (p = 
0.03) higher than in the K-M group (40 ± 16 vs. 34 ± 12 respectively). SpO
2 was significantly 
(p = 0.03) higher in the S-M group when compared to the K-M group (82 ± 6 vs. 79 ± 9 
respectively). 
 
The percentage of animals with adequate mus cle relaxation did not differ significantly 
between groups (p = 0.74). 
Mean percentage of animals that achieved su rgical anesthesia was significantly (p < 0.03) 
higher in the K-M group (56.25 ± 9.2%) than in the S-M group (42.5 ± 12.8%) (Figure 3). 
Palpebral reflexes ranged from spontaneous bl inking to delayed reaction but were maintained 
in all animals. In six out of 154 measurements (3.9%) palpebral reflex was absent. In four out  
20 
 of these six times (67%) this was immediately after induction. In the remaining two cases, 
absence was noted at one point during anesthesia  but it was present at the measurement right 
before and after the noted absence.  
Atipamezole was administered successfully via IM injection to all 20 hares in the study at  
T = 45. 
 
Recovery 
Chewing was observed in all animals before the first head lift. T-Anesthesia, T-Standing and 
T-Recovery are presented in Table 3. No si gnificant differences between groups were 
identified. There was, however, an overall, non significant tendency for shorter times in hares 
of the S-M group (Figure 4). Falling events were significantly higher (p = 0.02) in the K-M 
group (27.2 ± 12.56) than in the S-M group (12.5 ± 6.7). The S-M group had overall less 
pedaling events while in lateral recumbency, however, this was not significant (Figure 5). 
VAS values for recoveries, when compared betw een groups, were not significantly different. 
Here too, a trend towards better recovery for the S-M group was observed (Figure 4). 
 
   
 
   
 
   
 
 
 
  
21 
 Discussion 
According to this study, non surgical anesthesia in the EBH can be rapidly induced via IM 
administration of a combination of  either racemic ketamine (30 mg kg-1) or S(+)-ketamine (15 
mg kg-1) and medetomidine at 0.2 mg kg-1. The K-M group appeared to reach a deeper stage 
of anesthesia when compared to the S-M group. Respiratory parameters were significantly 
better in the S-M group. As reported in other sp ecies, these results suggest that S(+)-ketamine 
does not have an identical potency relationship to  the racemic mixture in EBHs as in humans 
(Marietta et al. 1977; Duque et al. 2008).  
 
Cardiovascular parameters during anesthesia were stable in both groups and did not differ in a 
clinically significant way. However, animals of both groups had long recovery times and 
severe emergence reactions. S(+)-ketamine dem onstrated a tendency to improve recovery 
parameters, like the number of times  the animal fell over to the side and the pedaling events. 
However, the extent of this effect  is minimal and in the author ’s opinion does not offer major 
advantages over racemic ketamine in this species. 
 
Injected volumes were relatively large at 0.52 ml kg-1 in both groups. Diehl et al. (2001) 
suggest volumes of 0.25 ml kg-1 for IM injection with a maximal  injectable volume of 0.5 ml 
kg-1 in rabbits. Since hares differ morphologically from rabbits and sub-cutaneous injection is 
prone to produce complications in a struggling an imal, IM injection into the caudal aspect of 
the pelvic limb was considered most suitable. This decision is supported by the fact that all 
hares tolerated injection well. The ban of IM ke tamine injections by the European Society of 
Laboratory Animal Veterinarians (ESLAV) be cause of pain upon injection and potential 
muscle necrosis was noted. However, minimal hand ling time, fast and safe injection and rapid 
induction led to IM injection as the only adequate route in this study. 
Dosages were chosen based upon suggestions made  for rabbits (Flecknell 2009; Erhardt et al. 
2004). Attention was given to research done by Avsaroglu et al. (2003) who identified strain 
specific differences in ketamine tolerance in  rabbits. Also Hunter & Isaza's (2008) study 
focusing on interspecies scaling was considered and risks linked with interspecies adoption of 
anesthetic protocols (West et al. 2009) were taken into account.  
 
Induction times for IM administered drugs (5 - 15 minutes) were within normal range (Muir et 
al. 2007). Drug dosages are inextricably linked with achievement of peak plasma  
22 
 concentrations (Riviere & Papich 2009). Tenden cy towards shorter induction times (time until 
full effect) in the K-M group could be attributed to the higher effective dose of ketamine. 
During anesthesia, no significant differences were identified in respect to cardiovascular 
parameters. This is in concorda nce with previous results of  comparative studies between 
racemic ketamine and S(+)-ketamine anesthesia made in mice (Kiliç & Henke 2004) and in 
horses (Rossetti et al. 2008). The recorded arrhythmias in the K-M group at beginning of 
anesthesia were not further described since no ECG was recorded. A higher incidence of 
arrhythmias when using racemic ketamine has been reported in humans (Hempelmann & 
Kuhn 1997). However, medetomidine as all alpha-2 agonists has arrhythmic potential and 
cannot be ruled out having triggered the observed arrhythmias (Muir et al. 2007).  
The significantly higher respiratory rate in the S-M group versus the K-M group is most 
probably due to the deeper stage of anesthesia  in the K-M group. Recently, Furtado et al. 
(2010) observed a decrease in respiratory rate during anesthesia in a group of black tufted 
marmosets (Callithrix penicillata)  anesthetized with racemic ketamine in combination with 
midazolam that was not observed in the group receiving S(+)-ketamine and midazolam. Even 
though equimolar dosages of racemic ketamine a nd S(+)-ketamine were used by Furtado et 
al., their results should be taken into account. Ultimately, etCO2 and SpO2 are controlled by 
respiration. The different RR recorded could be partially responsible for the different mean 
values of the parameters between groups. Due to  lack of other respiratory parameters (i.e. 
minute volume, etc.), this cannot be confirme d. The capnograph probe was only left in one 
nostril for one minute of each measurement si nce lagomorphs are primary to obligate nasal 
breathers (West et al. 2009) and increased respir atory work was tried to be avoided. A deeper 
stage of anesthesia in the K-M group might also  hint that S(+)-ketamine possibly does not 
have equal potency advantages over its racemic  mixture in the EBH as it does in humans. 
The low SpO 2 values recorded by pulse oximetry c ould be due to hypoxemia. To the author ’s 
opinion, the extent of lower saturation in this stud y is more likely due to pulse oximetry errors 
(Hummler et al. 2006; Orr et al. 2005) or va soconstriction caused by medetomidine than 
actual saturation values. Unfortunately, this canno t be confirmed as no blood gas analysis was 
performed in this study. Since a certain de gree of hypoxemia is anticipated, oxygen 
supplementation should be considered if feasible under field conditions. 
 
 In all animals, both anesthetic regimens pr oduced a sufficient state of anesthesia for blood 
sampling and non invasive measures that could be  of interest in the field. However, surgical  
23 
 depth for possible implantation of very high fr equency (VHF) transmitters or probes was not 
reliably achieved with either racemic ketamine at 30 mg kg-1 nor S(+)-ketamine at 15 mg kg-1 
in combination with medetomidine at 0.2 mg kg-1. Toe pinch, as a test for surgical anesthesia 
depth, was positive in many animals after the second pinch only. This is supported by 
Hedenqvist et al. (2001) and Kiliç & Henke (2004)  who found that if only a single nail pinch 
was applied as a test for surgical anesthesia in rabbits, many animals would not have shown 
any reaction. 
 
Increasing the dosage of either one or both of the anesthetics used could deepen anesthesia. 
Since palpebral reflexes were maintained and no  case of apnea occurred at the dosages used 
this appears to be a suitable approach. Yet, it would increase anesthetic risk and injectable 
volume. A deepening of anesthesia with isoflura ne as suggested by Flecknell (2009) and Orr 
et al. (2005) is common practice but  often impracticable in field an esthesia situations. To the 
author ’s opinion infiltration or blocks with local anesthetics as suggested by Flecknell (2009) 
or adjunct of metamizol as suggested by Er hardt et al. (2004) should be considered.  
 
The results for palpebral reflex are to be critically evaluated since no consistent lack of 
palpebral reflex was recorded. When palpebral reflex was absent at the beginning of 
anesthesia, eye ointment had just been applied wh ich might have had an influence. It needs to 
be stated generally that ocular (and other) reflexes are mostly maintained during ketamine 
based anesthesia (Erhardt et al. 2004; Muir et al. 2007). 
Noticeable are the results for the recovery parame ters. Large differences concerning recovery 
times can be found in the literature about lagomorphs. West et al. (2009) state “ Ketamine has 
a very short duration of clinical effect, owing, in  part, to redistribution and renal elimination” 
whereas Erhardt et al. (2004) report hangover times of up to 10 h for ketamine-xylazine 
combinations in rabbits. Bjorkman & Redke (2000) found that in all the animal species within 
their study, except for the rabbit, ketamine c learance was lower than hepatic blood flow. 
Whereas, in the rabbit, ketamine showed extensive  extrahepatic clearance. Medetomidine is 
known to significantly reduce hepatic micros omal metabolism of ketamine in human liver 
samples in vitro (Kharasch et al. 1992). To the author ’s knowledge there is no study 
concerning inhibition of extrahepatic ketamine- clearance in other species.  Duration of the 
EBH’s recovery in our study encourages further investigation on this topic in the future.   
24 
 Different information regarding time points of  partial antagonization of ketamine – α2-agonist 
combinations can be found in the literature. A tipamezole was administered at T = 45 min after 
administration of the induction agents. This is  later than Flecknell (2009) at ketamine dosages 
of 15 mg kg-1 and sooner than Erhardt (2004) at dosages of 35 mg kg-1 suggest for rabbits.  
Total anesthesia times were similar but showed great variance in both groups with a mean of 
65 ± 13 minutes in the S-M and 70 ± 22 minutes  in the K-M group respectively. Get up time 
on average was slightly shorter in the S-M group 30 ± 25 vs. 34 ± 23 minutes in the K-M 
group. Yet, ranges in both groups were considerably large.  
One animal in the study showed high grad e excitations starting at 75 minutes post 
antagonization and had to be caught again to su ture a skin lesion that occurred during the 
agitated behavior phase.  
For this reason a cushioned and darkened wake up box was constructed. In the following, all 
animals were put in this box after antagoniza tion. Only one hare of the S-M group appeared 
fully recovered at 92 minutes post antagonization. All other hares had major hangover signs 
for up to 180 minutes. When possible, monitoring was discontinued at 180 minutes post 
antagonization.  
During recovery, the K-M group showed a markedly higher incidence of disorientation and 
lack of balance than the S-M group. This included running against walls and flipping over in 
some cases. Ketamine is known to produce ataxia and increased motor activity during 
recovery and this fact has been previously reviewed (Wright 1982). Higher incidences of 
unccordinated or involuntary movements when  using racemic ketamine in comparative 
studies with S(+)-ketamine in different species have been reported previously (White et al. 
1982; Erhardt et al. 2001; Kiliç & Henke 2004; Larenza et al. 2008; Rossetti et al. 2008). 
 
The VAS is a common tool used for the a ssessment of subjective impressions (Grint & 
Murison 2008; Portier et al. 2010). In this study it was taken as a measure for recovery 
quality. To reduce possible bias it was always done by the same anesthetist blinded about the 
protocol. Yet, since no evaluation of anesthesia recovery in EBH had ever been performed 
previously, expectations based on experience w ith recoveries in other species may have 
influenced results. However, it can be clea rly stated that overall recovery was inadequate 
especially for field procedures.   
  
25 
 Using S(+)-ketamine had no clinically significant effect on anesthesia time. Less undesired 
side effects during recovery were recorded when S(+)-ketamine was used, but in general both 
protocols produced long recoveries and no reliable surgical anesthesia. Therefore, at the 
dosages used, ketamine based anesthetic regimens (for field anesthesia protocols in particular) 
are not recommended for the EBH. In the author ’s opinion, ketamine is to be critically 
evaluated as an adjunct of anesthetic regimens in this species. If ketamine is used, a 
completely cushioned recovery box is necessary to avoid potential injuries such as skin 
lesions or even fractures. Not only for reliable achievement of surgical depth, but also for 
animal welfare reasons further re search is needed to develop an anesthetic regimen suitable 
for the EBH under field conditions.  
26 
 Acknowledgements 
The author would like to thank all the people involved in the realization of this study. 
   
27

 Summary 
 
This is a comparative study of two anesth etic protocols based on medetomidine in 
combination with either racemic ketamine or S(+)-ketamine in the European brown hare 
(EBH) ( Lepus europaeus). 
Availability of tested protocols for wildlife that is of interest for research purposes deems 
necessary. Literature based anesthetic regimens used for the EBH in the past did not seem 
adequate anymore. 
Since Lagomorphs are known for higher anesthetic risk it was tried to develop a protocol that 
would reliably produce safe, surgical anesthesia with a brief recovery period, suitable for field 
anesthesia. 
20 EBHs were anesthetized for routine procedures. All parameters recorded in the study were 
subject to statistical analysis . Times until first and full effect were recorded and during 
maintenance the animals' vital parameters were measured in a five minute interval. Special 
focus was set on recovery parameters. Total an esthesia time, Standing time and Recovery 
time were noted. Additionally, the number of times  the animal fell over or was pedaling in 
lateral position were recorded. A visual analogue scale was used for subj ective assessment of 
recovery quality. All personnel evaluating anesth esia were blinded about the protocol used.  
At the dosages of 15 mg kg-1 S(+)-ketamine or 30 mg kg-1 racemic ketamine in combination 
with 0.2 mg kg-1 medetomidine did not reliably produce surgical anesthesia. Overall, animals 
receiving the racemic ketamine reached a deeper state of anesthesia and had more respiratory 
depression than the S(+)-ketamine group. Unfo rtunately, the idea of using S(+)-ketamine 
instead of racemic ketamine did not markedl y improve recovery. Even though slight 
improvements were noted in the S(+)-ketamine group, recovery frequently exceeded two 
hours in both groups. Recovery in most cases was accompanied by uncoordinated movements 
and involuntary motoractivity. We conclude that further research is needed to develop an 
injectable field anesthesia protocol for the EBH that guarantees surgical anesthesia while 
producing minimal unwanted side effects during recovery and therefore diminishes animal 
welfare issues.  
41 
 Zusammenfassung 
Dies ist eine Vergleichsstudie zweier Protokolle zur Feld-Narkose des Europäischen 
Feldhasen (EFH) ( Lepus europaeus ). Es wurde die Wirkung von 0,2 mg kg-1 Medetomidin in 
Kombination mit entweder 15 mg kg-1 S-(+)-Ketamin oder 30 mg kg-1 razemischem Ketamin 
verglichen. 
Spezies-spezifische Anästhesie ist vor allem für Wildtiere angebracht, die im 
Forschungsinteresse stehen. Große tierartliche Unterschiede im Bereich der 
Haustieranästhesie sind hinlänglich bekannt. Einfache Übertragung von Haustierprotokollen 
auf Wildtiere hat sich in der Verg angenheit als ungenügend dargestellt. 
Im Rahmen einer Routineuntersuchung wurden  20 Feldhasen des Forschungsinstituts für 
Wildtierkunde und Ökologie der Veterinärmedizini schen Universität Wien in zwei Gruppen á 
10 Tiere aufgeteilt und mit einem der oben  erwähnten Protokolle anästhesiert. 
Erstreaktionszeit, sowie die Zeit bis zum vollen Effekt (Verlust des Stell-Reflexes) wurden 
dokumentiert und verglichen. Während der Anästh esie wurden die Vitalparameter der Tiere 
alle 5 Minuten kontrolliert und im Anschluss an die Studie statistisch ausgewertet. Besonderes 
Augenmerk wurde auf die Parameter der Aufwach- und Erholungsphase gelegt. Da es sich um 
ein Protokoll für eine Feldnarkose handelt, wurden Narkosezeit, Aufstehzeit und 
Regenerationszeit gemessen und zwischen beid en Gruppen verglichen. Zusätzlich wurde 
gezählt, wie oft die Tiere in der Erholungsphase  umfielen oder in Seitenlage ruderten, um ein 
Maß für eingeschränkte Koordinationsfähigkeit zu schaffen. Zusammen mit einer visuellen 
analogen Skala zur subjektiven Einschätzung der Qualität der Aufwachphase, wurden auch 
diese Werte auf signifikante Unterschiede zwischen den beiden Gruppen untersucht. 
Tiere, die razemisches Ketamin als Komponente bekommen hatten, erreichten ein tieferes 
Anästhesiestadium als die Tiere aus der S-(+)-Ketamin Gruppe. Die respiratorischen 
Parameter in der S-(+)-Ketamin Gruppe waren signifikant besser. Insgesamt wurde jedoch in 
keiner Gruppe die chirurgische Toleranz verl ässlich erreicht. Eine lange Aufwachphase mit 
teils hochgradigen unkoordinierten und unfreiwilligen Bewegungen wurde hingegen 
regelmäßig beobachtet. 
Die Nutzung des S-(+)-Isomers des Ketamins br achte hinsichtlich der Aufwachphase zwar 
geringfügige, aber keine klinisch relevante n Vorteile gegenüber dem razemischen Gemisch. 
Es bedarf daher weiterer Untersuchungen um  ein, für den EFH geeignetes, Protokoll zur 
Feldnarkose zu entwickeln. Eine sichere Anäs thesie mit chirurgischer Toleranz und einer  
42 
 kurzen Aufwachphase mit möglichst wenigen unerwünschten Nebenwirkungen sollte auch 
aus Sicht des Tierschutzes das Ziel sein.
